Articles.Content:
Ok, I've made an able craft to launch three people to the MUN!!! DUN DUN DUH. Anyways, during a certain stage, the rocket randomly explodes. It's when I decouple. I don't think there should be a reason it explodes, cause it's in SPACE, unless there's oxygen in the tanks, which is plausible. I decouple the large orange tank from my "lander" and when i do that, the engines on my lander explode and come right off the ship, where my kerbals are hopeless to survive, and they are Bill, Jeb, and Ernie (bob's on the Mun) and I restart not wanting dead brothers on bob's hands.

EDIT: I have serperatons, to disengage the Orange tank, since the first stages needed them

Edited May 21, 2013 by Matthewx777
Its hard to tell whats going on without pics.
I know, but I can't post attachments :'(
is the tank hitting somthing?

Ok, I've made an able craft to launch three people to the MUN!!! DUN DUN DUH. Anyways, during a certain stage, the rocket randomly explodes. It's when I decouple. I don't think there should be a reason it explodes, cause it's in SPACE, unless there's oxygen in the tanks, which is plausible. I decouple the large orange tank from my "lander" and when i do that, the engines on my lander explode and come right off the ship, where my kerbals are hopeless to survive, and they are Bill, Jeb, and Ernie (bob's on the Mun) and I restart not wanting dead brothers on bob's hands.

This is most likely caused by the tiniest touch of the fuel tank to your ship. The only fix to this is use the decoupler that adds the biggest gap between you and the empty tank, also add some sepatrons onto it to make it "boost" away from your ship causing "hopefully" no damage! If that does not work I would like to see your craft file to see if I can fix the problem.
it says the engine collided with the tank

All I had to do was change the coupler. Easy fix, also your welcome!
I have exactly the same problem - what did you change on the coupler austin?

Could have been a case where the tank/SRB was being attached directly to the side instead of being attached to the radial decoupler. When attaching things to the radial decouplers, just make sure you're actually attaching the part you want to drop to the decoupler. Otherwise, when the decoupler is staged, it blows up against the fixed part you want to drop.
Next time, press F3. It shows you exactly what's blowing up. From there it is a lot easier to figure it out.
